Administrators must manually assign users to specific compute locations based on their primary office location.
All traffic routes through a single designated regional gateway to maintain consistent security policy application.
Users select their preferred compute location from the GlobalProtect client interface each time they connect.
explanation:
Prisma Access infrastructure automatically optimizes user connections through its global network of compute locations.

1. Automatic Location Selection:
   • When GlobalProtect connects, the infrastructure determines the optimal compute location
   • Based on IP geolocation, DNS resolution, and latency measurements
   • No manual assignment required—users get optimal location automatically
   • Traveling users connect to nearest location regardless of 'home' office

2. Global Infrastructure:
   • 100+ compute locations worldwide
   • Locations in major metropolitan areas across NA, EU, APAC, etc.
   • Sub-50ms latency achievable for most global business locations
   • Consistent security stack at every location

3. High Availability:
   • Each compute location has built-in redundancy
   • If a location experiences issues, traffic routes to next-nearest
   • Automatic failover without user intervention
   • No single point of failure for the global service

4. Data Sovereignty (EU):
   • Prisma Access offers regional deployment options
   • EU-resident users can be configured to use EU compute locations only
   • Traffic processing and logging occurs within designated region
   • Addresses GDPR and data residency requirements

Configuration for Data Residency:
• Create separate Mobile User configuration for EU users
• Specify EU-only compute location constraints
• EU traffic never processed outside designated region

How the 50ms Requirement is Met:
• Global distribution means users are physically close to compute locations
• Anycast routing directs users to optimal entry point
• Direct peering with major ISPs and cloud providers
• Premium network backbone between compute locations

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. Manual assignment to compute locations: This defeats the purpose of a global cloud service. Administrators don't need to (and shouldn't) manually assign users to locations. Manual assignment would create poor experience for traveling users and scaling challenges for 15,000 users.

C. Single regional gateway: Routing all global traffic through one gateway would create terrible latency for distant users. A user in Tokyo connecting through a US gateway would have 150-200ms+ latency, failing the 50ms requirement.

D. Users select location: Users don't select compute locations from the GlobalProtect interface. The selection is automatic and transparent. User-driven selection would create confusion and suboptimal choices.

Key exam point: Prisma Access auto-selects optimal compute locations. Data residency requirements use regional constraints, not manual user assignment.

question:
A SOC team needs to integrate Prisma Access logs with their existing SIEM infrastructure (Splunk) for security monitoring and compliance. Their requirements include:

• Real-time threat alerts must be forwarded within 60 seconds
• All traffic logs must be retained for 1 year for compliance
• Logs must be in Common Event Format (CEF) for SIEM parsing
• The SIEM must be able to correlate Prisma Access logs with firewall logs

Which TWO configurations are required to meet these requirements?
options: Configure Log Forwarding to send logs to a syslog server in CEF format, with the syslog server forwarding to Splunk.
Enable the Cortex Data Lake to Splunk integration app for native log streaming with automatic field mapping.
Configure Prisma Access to write logs directly to Splunk's HEC (HTTP Event Collector) endpoint.
Set up SNMP traps from Prisma Access to the SIEM for real-time threat alerting.
explanation:
Integrating Prisma Access logs with external SIEM requires understanding the logging architecture and available integration methods.

A. Syslog Forwarding in CEF Format:

How it works:
• Prisma Access stores logs in Cortex Data Lake (cloud-based logging)
• Configure Log Forwarding to send logs to external syslog server
• Specify CEF (Common Event Format) for SIEM compatibility
• Syslog server can be on-premises, forwarding to Splunk

Configuration:
• In Strata Cloud Manager: Device > Log Forwarding
• Define syslog server profiles with IP, port, format
• Select log types to forward (traffic, threat, URL, etc.)
• CEF format ensures standard field mapping

Benefits:
• CEF is widely supported by SIEMs including Splunk
• Near real-time forwarding (typically <60 seconds)
• Standard format enables correlation with other CEF sources
• Intermediate syslog server can buffer and transform if needed

B. Cortex Data Lake to Splunk Integration:

How it works:
• Palo Alto provides a Splunk app/add-on for Cortex Data Lake
• Direct API-based log streaming from CDL to Splunk
• Automatic field mapping and parsing
• Native integration maintained by Palo Alto

Benefits:
• No intermediate syslog server required
• Optimized for Palo Alto log formats
• Includes dashboards and correlation rules
• Supports long-term retention queries against CDL

For 1-year retention:
• Cortex Data Lake provides cloud log storage
• Retention periods configurable up to required duration
• Splunk receives streaming copy for active analysis
• CDL serves as compliance archive

Let's analyze why the other options don't work:

C. Direct HEC endpoint from Prisma Access: Prisma Access doesn't support direct HTTP Event Collector output. Logs go to Cortex Data Lake first, then can be forwarded via syslog or the CDL integration. There's no native HEC output configuration in Prisma Access.

D. SNMP traps for threat alerting: Prisma Access doesn't use SNMP traps for log forwarding or alerting. SNMP is typically used for infrastructure monitoring (CPU, memory, tunnel status), not security event forwarding. Log-based alerting uses syslog or API integration.

Key exam point: Prisma Access logs → Cortex Data Lake → SIEM via syslog (CEF) or native CDL integration app.

question:
An organization is migrating from traditional VPN to ZTNA 2.0 for application access. They have identified a legacy application with these characteristics:

• Client-server architecture using custom TCP port 8443
• Application performs health checks by connecting back to the client
• Users need access from both managed laptops and personal mobile devices
• The application server is in an on-premises data center

Which ZTNA deployment approach accommodates this application's requirements?
options: Deploy ZTNA Connector in the data center, configure bidirectional access rules, and use both GlobalProtect (managed devices) and Explicit Proxy (personal devices) for user connectivity.
Configure a Remote Network connection with NAT, as ZTNA doesn't support applications requiring bidirectional connectivity.
Use Prisma Access Browser for all users to access the application through a web wrapper, avoiding connectivity complexity.
Deploy the application in a DMZ with public IP addressing, as ZTNA only supports applications accessible from the internet.
explanation:
ZTNA 2.0 with ZTNA Connector supports complex application architectures including bidirectional connectivity. Here's how to address each requirement:

1. ZTNA Connector Deployment:
   • Install ZTNA Connector in the data center
   • Connector establishes outbound tunnel to Prisma Access
   • No inbound firewall rules required at data center
   • Connector provides access to on-premises applications

2. Custom Port Support:
   • ZTNA isn't limited to HTTP/HTTPS (ports 80/443)
   • Configure application definition for TCP port 8443
   • App-ID can identify and control the specific application
   • Full Layer 7 inspection available

3. Bidirectional Connectivity:
   • Challenge: Application server connects back to client
   • ZTNA Connector supports this through tunnel routing
   • Configure bidirectional access policies
   • Server-initiated connections route through same tunnel
   • This is a key ZTNA 2.0 capability vs. traditional ZTNA

4. Multi-Device Access:
   
   Managed Laptops (GlobalProtect):
   • Full GlobalProtect agent installed
   • HIP checks verify device compliance
   • Tunnel provides network-level access
   • All security policies applied

   Personal Mobile Devices (Explicit Proxy):
   • No agent installation required
   • Browser-based proxy configuration
   • SAML authentication for identity
   • Access without device management

5. Configuration Steps:
   • Define application in Strata Cloud Manager (IP, port 8443)
   • Associate with ZTNA Connector Group
   • Create access policies for both GP and Explicit Proxy users
   • Enable bidirectional application support

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. Remote Network instead of ZTNA: This is incorrect on two counts. First, ZTNA 2.0 does support bidirectional connectivity—that's one of its enhancements. Second, Remote Network connections are for site-to-site connectivity, not application-specific access. This approach would expose more network surface than necessary.

C. Prisma Access Browser: While the secure browser provides isolation, it's designed for web applications. A custom TCP port 8443 client-server application cannot be 'wrapped' in a browser interface. It requires actual client connectivity, not browser rendering.

D. DMZ with public IP: This fundamentally misunderstands ZTNA. The entire point is to avoid exposing applications to the internet. ZTNA Connector enables access without public IP exposure. Putting the application in a DMZ with public IP creates unnecessary attack surface.

Key exam point: ZTNA 2.0 supports: bidirectional apps, non-HTTP protocols, and both agent (GP) and agentless (Explicit Proxy) access methods.

question:
The security operations team receives an alert that a user's device has been communicating with a known command-and-control server. Initial investigation in Prisma Access logs shows:

• Multiple DNS queries to the C2 domain over the past 24 hours
• Successful HTTPS connections to the C2 IP address
• The user is a mobile user connecting via GlobalProtect
• Anti-Spyware profile generated alerts but connections were allowed

What sequence of actions should the SOC team take to contain and investigate this incident?
options: Quarantine the user by disabling their account in Cloud Identity Engine, review detailed session logs in Cortex Data Lake, update Anti-Spyware profile to block the threat category, and coordinate endpoint investigation.
Immediately block all traffic from the user's IP address at the Prisma Access firewall level, then investigate later.
Wait for WildFire to complete analysis of any downloaded files before taking containment action.
Contact the user to manually disconnect from GlobalProtect and run antivirus scan before investigating further.
explanation:
Effective incident response requires immediate containment followed by investigation, not the reverse. The correct sequence addresses both urgency and thoroughness:

1. Quarantine the User (Immediate Containment):
   
   Why disable in Cloud Identity Engine:
   • Immediately revokes user's ability to authenticate
   • GlobalProtect session terminates when reauth is required
   • Prevents further C2 communication through Prisma Access
   • Doesn't require knowing the user's current IP (which may change)
   • Faster than modifying security policies

   This is the quickest containment method that:
   • Stops the threat actor's access
   • Preserves evidence (doesn't wipe anything)
   • Is reversible once investigation completes

2. Review Session Logs in Cortex Data Lake:
   
   Investigation queries:
   • All DNS queries from the user (identify additional C2 domains)
   • HTTPS session details (data volume transferred)
   • File downloads that may indicate malware delivery
   • Timeline of compromise (when did C2 communication start?)
   • Other users communicating with same C2 infrastructure

   Cortex Data Lake provides:
   • Full session logging including decrypted content metadata
   • Historical queries beyond real-time dashboards
   • Correlation capabilities across log types

3. Update Anti-Spyware Profile:
   
   Why connections were 'allowed':
   • Profile may have been set to 'alert' for medium severity
   • Specific C2 signature may not have had block action
   
   Remediation:
   • Change action to 'block' or 'reset-both' for this threat category
   • Consider enabling DNS Security C2 blocking
   • Prevents future incidents with same threat type

4. Coordinate Endpoint Investigation:
   
   Why endpoint matters:
   • C2 communication indicates endpoint compromise
   • Malware needs to be identified and removed
   • Forensic analysis determines initial infection vector
   • Endpoint team may use EDR (Cortex XDR) for detailed analysis

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. Block user's IP address: Mobile users have dynamic IP addresses. Blocking one IP is ineffective—the user reconnects with a new IP. Also, 'block and investigate later' delays containment while waiting for policy deployment.

C. Wait for WildFire analysis: This delays containment. The C2 communication is already confirmed—waiting for file analysis allows continued data exfiltration. Containment should be immediate; WildFire analysis informs the investigation but shouldn't delay action.

D. Contact user to disconnect: This relies on the user's availability and compliance. A compromised device may have malware that reconnects automatically. Administrative containment (disabling the account) is more reliable than user-dependent actions.

Key exam point: Incident response sequence: Contain (identity-based revocation) → Investigate (CDL logs) → Remediate (policy update) → Coordinate (endpoint team).

question:
A managed security service provider (MSSP) wants to offer Prisma Access as a service to multiple customers. Their requirements include:

• Complete policy isolation between customers
• Centralized management from a single console
• Individual customer branding on GlobalProtect portals
• Separate logging and reporting per customer
• Ability for customers to manage their own policies within defined boundaries

Which architectural approach enables this service model?
options: Deploy Prisma Access with multitenancy enabled, creating separate tenants for each customer with delegated administration and isolated policy domains.
Create separate Prisma Access instances for each customer, managed through individual Strata Cloud Manager consoles.
Use a single Prisma Access tenant with security zones to logically separate customer traffic and policies.
Deploy on-premises Panorama to manage multiple cloud-based Prisma Access deployments for different customers.
explanation:
Prisma Access multitenancy is specifically designed for MSSP and enterprise scenarios requiring complete tenant isolation with centralized management.

1. Tenant Isolation:
   • Each customer exists as a separate tenant within the MSSP's Prisma Access deployment
   • Complete policy isolation—one customer's rules never affect another
   • Separate configuration namespaces for objects (address groups, security profiles)
   • No cross-tenant visibility or policy inheritance risks

2. Centralized Management:
   • MSSP manages all tenants from a single Strata Cloud Manager console
   • Global visibility across all customers for operational efficiency
   • Shared infrastructure reduces operational overhead
   • Template-based provisioning for consistent baseline security

3. Delegated Administration:
   • Role-based access control (RBAC) per tenant
   • Customer administrators can manage their own policies
   • MSSP defines boundaries (what customers can/cannot modify)
   • Separation of duties between MSSP and customer teams

4. Custom Branding:
   • GlobalProtect portals can be branded per tenant
   • Customer logos and messaging on authentication pages
   • White-label appearance for MSSP services

5. Separate Logging:
   • Logs are segregated by tenant in Cortex Data Lake
   • Customer-specific dashboards and reports
   • MSSP can access all logs; customers see only their own
   • Compliance reporting per customer

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. Separate Prisma Access instances: This would require managing multiple completely independent deployments. It eliminates centralized management efficiency, increases cost (separate licenses), and complicates operations. Multitenancy provides the same isolation with single-platform management.

C. Security zones for separation: Zones provide traffic segmentation, not policy isolation. A single-tenant deployment with zones doesn't provide the administrative separation, logging isolation, or delegated management that MSSPs require. All policies would be visible to all administrators.

D. On-premises Panorama: Panorama can manage Prisma Access, but it doesn't create the multitenancy architecture. Without Prisma Access multitenancy enabled, Panorama would just manage a single-tenant deployment. Panorama isn't the source of multitenancy—it's an optional management layer.

Key exam point: Multitenancy = complete tenant isolation + centralized MSSP management + delegated customer administration.

question:
An organization is implementing WildFire analysis in Prisma Access for advanced malware protection. Their security team requires:

• Maximum protection against zero-day threats
• Analysis of files before users can download them
• Detection of malware that evades virtual machine analysis
• Minimal impact on user experience for legitimate files

Which TWO configurations should be enabled to meet these requirements?
options: Enable 'Hold for Verdict' to prevent file downloads until WildFire analysis is complete, with a timeout to release files if analysis takes too long.
Configure WildFire to use bare metal analysis environments for files that exhibit VM-evasive behaviors.
Set WildFire to 'Inline ML' mode only, disabling cloud analysis to reduce latency.
Configure file forwarding only for executable files (.exe, .dll) to minimize analysis load.
explanation:
WildFire provides multi-technique malware analysis. Two specific configurations address the stated requirements:

A. Hold for Verdict:

How it works:
• When a user downloads a file, it's sent to WildFire for analysis
• The download is held (not delivered) until WildFire returns a verdict
• If WildFire determines the file is malicious, download is blocked
• If benign, file is released to the user

Addressing Requirements:
• 'Analysis before download' requirement is directly satisfied
• Zero-day protection because new malware is caught before execution
• Timeout prevents indefinite waiting (typically 5-10 minutes max)
• Previously analyzed files (hash match) are released immediately

User Experience Considerations:
• First-seen files experience delay (typically <5 minutes for verdict)
• Known-good files with matching hash are released instantly
• Timeout ensures users aren't blocked forever
• Trade-off between security and convenience—appropriate for high-security orgs

B. Bare Metal Analysis:

How it works:
• Standard WildFire analysis uses virtual machines (VMs)
• Sophisticated malware detects VM environments and doesn't execute malicious behavior
• Bare metal analysis runs files on actual hardware
• No VM artifacts for malware to detect

Addressing Requirements:
• 'Malware that evades VM analysis' is caught through bare metal
• WildFire automatically escalates suspicious files to bare metal
• Maximum protection against advanced evasive techniques
• Catches APT-grade malware designed to evade sandboxes

WildFire Analysis Chain:
1. Static analysis (file structure, signatures)
2. Dynamic analysis in VM sandbox
3. If VM-evasion detected → bare metal analysis
4. Machine learning models for final classification

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

C. Inline ML only, disable cloud analysis: Inline ML provides immediate protection but is a complement to, not replacement for, full WildFire analysis. Disabling cloud analysis removes the deep behavioral analysis that detects sophisticated malware. Inline ML alone misses many advanced threats.

D. Only executable files: This creates significant gaps. Malware is commonly delivered through:
• PDF documents (embedded scripts)
• Office files (macros)
• Archives (ZIP, RAR containing malware)
• Script files (PowerShell, JavaScript)
Limiting to .exe/.dll misses major attack vectors.

Key exam point: Hold for Verdict = block-before-analysis. Bare metal = anti-VM-evasion. Both maximize zero-day protection.

question:
A network engineer is troubleshooting a Remote Network connection to Prisma Access. The IPsec tunnel was working but has stopped passing traffic. Diagnostic logs show:

• IKE Phase 1 negotiation succeeds
• IKE Phase 2 fails with 'No proposal chosen'
• No changes were made to the on-premises router configuration
• Other Remote Network tunnels to the same Prisma Access location are working

What is the most likely cause of this issue?
options: The Prisma Access IPsec crypto profile was updated with new encryption/authentication algorithms that the on-premises router doesn't support.
The IKE pre-shared key has expired and needs to be renewed on both sides.
The on-premises router's public IP address changed, causing Prisma Access to reject the connection.
Phase 1 success means Phase 2 should also succeed; the logs are likely corrupted.
explanation:
'No proposal chosen' is a specific IPsec error indicating the two endpoints cannot agree on security parameters. This occurs during IKE Phase 2 negotiation.

Understanding IPsec Phases:

• IKE Phase 1 (IKE SA):
  - Authenticates peers (PSK or certificate)
  - Establishes secure channel for Phase 2
  - Negotiates encryption, hash, DH group for IKE itself
  - Success means: authentication passed, IKE channel established

• IKE Phase 2 (IPsec SA):
  - Negotiates parameters for actual data encryption
  - Encryption algorithm (AES-128, AES-256, etc.)
  - Authentication/integrity (SHA-256, SHA-384, etc.)
  - PFS group if enabled
  - Must have at least one matching proposal

'No Proposal Chosen' Analysis:

1. Phase 1 succeeded: This eliminates PSK mismatch, peer identity issues, and IKE-level algorithm incompatibility.

2. Phase 2 failed: The IPsec (ESP) transform set proposals don't match between endpoints.

3. 'No changes to on-premises router': Suggests Prisma Access side changed.

4. Other tunnels working: The Prisma Access location is operational; issue is specific to this tunnel's parameters.

Most Likely Scenario:
• Prisma Access crypto profile was updated (perhaps globally or by template)
• New settings require stronger algorithms (e.g., AES-256-GCM, SHA-384)
• On-premises router doesn't have these algorithms configured or supported
• Phase 2 negotiation fails because no common proposal exists

Resolution:
• Check Prisma Access IPsec crypto profile for this Remote Network
• Compare with on-premises router's Phase 2 proposals
• Either update router to match new Prisma Access settings
• Or revert Prisma Access crypto profile to compatible settings

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. Pre-shared key expired: PSK doesn't 'expire' in IPsec. If PSK was wrong, Phase 1 would fail with authentication error, not Phase 2 with 'no proposal chosen.' Phase 1 succeeded, so PSK is correct.

C. Public IP changed: If the router's IP changed, IKE Phase 1 might fail with peer identification issues. But Phase 1 succeeded. Also, many IKEv2 configurations use dynamic addressing without issue. This wouldn't cause 'no proposal chosen.'

D. Logs corrupted: This dismisses valid diagnostic information. Phase 1 and Phase 2 are distinct negotiations that can succeed/fail independently. 'No proposal chosen' is a legitimate error message indicating real misconfiguration.

Key exam point: 'No proposal chosen' = Phase 2 transform set mismatch. Check encryption/authentication algorithms on both ends.

question:
A security architect is designing GlobalProtect authentication for a defense contractor. Requirements include:

• Users must authenticate with both 'something they have' and 'something they know'
• Authentication must work when users are not connected to the corporate network
• Compromised passwords alone should not grant VPN access
• The solution must integrate with existing PKI infrastructure

Which authentication configuration meets these requirements?
options: Certificate-based authentication using client certificates from the corporate PKI, combined with LDAP username/password verification through Cloud Identity Engine.
SAML authentication with Azure AD MFA, using push notifications as the second factor.
RADIUS authentication with one-time password tokens generated by a hardware key fob.
Kerberos authentication with smart card certificates for single sign-on from domain-joined devices.
explanation:
Certificate plus password authentication provides true multi-factor authentication (MFA) that leverages existing PKI infrastructure.

1. Two-Factor Requirements Satisfied:

   Something You Have (Factor 1):
   • Client certificate stored on the device or hardware token
   • Issued by corporate PKI (internal Certificate Authority)
   • Private key is device-bound, can't be easily copied
   • Certificate proves possession of specific device/token

   Something You Know (Factor 2):
   • LDAP username and password
   • Verified against Active Directory via Cloud Identity Engine
   • User must know their credentials
   • Password alone is insufficient (certificate also required)

2. Works Without Corporate Network:
   • Cloud Identity Engine syncs directory information to the cloud
   • Password verification doesn't require direct LDAP connectivity
   • Certificate validation uses configured trust chain
   • Mobile users can authenticate from anywhere

3. Protection Against Compromised Passwords:
   • Even if attacker obtains username/password
   • They cannot authenticate without the client certificate
   • Certificate private key is not transmitted
   • Requires compromise of both factors

4. PKI Integration:
   • Uses existing corporate CA infrastructure
   • Certificates issued through normal enterprise processes
   • Can leverage smart cards, TPM-bound certificates
   • Certificate lifecycle managed by PKI team

GlobalProtect Configuration:
• Portal/Gateway: Require client certificate
• Authentication profile: LDAP/Cloud Identity Engine
• Certificate profile: Trust corporate CA chain
• Authentication sequence: Certificate + password (both required)

Let's analyze why the other options don't fully meet requirements:

B. SAML with Azure AD MFA: This is a valid MFA solution, but:
• It doesn't directly integrate with 'existing PKI infrastructure'
• Azure AD is the identity provider, not the corporate PKI
• Push notifications are 'something you have' but not PKI-based

C. RADIUS with OTP tokens: Also valid MFA, but:
• Hardware tokens are separate from PKI infrastructure
• Doesn't leverage existing PKI as required
• OTP is 'something you have' but not certificate-based

D. Kerberos with smart cards: Addresses PKI through smart cards, but:
• Kerberos requires connectivity to domain controllers
• 'When not connected to corporate network' is problematic
• Kerberos is typically for on-network authentication

Key exam point: Certificate + password = true MFA using PKI. Certificate = 'something you have', password = 'something you know'.

question:
An organization is planning Prisma Access deployment and needs to understand licensing. Their environment includes:

• 5,000 mobile users requiring GlobalProtect access
• 10 branch offices requiring Remote Network connections
• 2 data centers requiring Service Connections
• Enterprise DLP, CASB, and ADEM capabilities needed

Which licensing model applies to this deployment?
options: Mobile User licenses are based on user count, Remote Networks on bandwidth, and Service Connections are included. Security services (DLP, CASB, ADEM) require additional subscriptions.
A single enterprise license covers unlimited users, sites, and all security features for a flat annual fee.
Licensing is purely consumption-based, calculated monthly based on actual bandwidth and user connections.
Each component (mobile users, remote networks, service connections, security services) is licensed separately with independent contracts.
explanation:
Prisma Access licensing follows a structured model with base capacity licensing plus security service subscriptions.

1. Mobile User Licensing:
   • Licensed by user count (e.g., 5,000 users)
   • Determines maximum concurrent GlobalProtect connections
   • Includes bandwidth allocation per user tier
   • Users can connect from any location globally

2. Remote Network Licensing:
   • Licensed by bandwidth (e.g., 100 Mbps, 500 Mbps, 1 Gbps per site)
   • Each Remote Network location consumes allocated bandwidth
   • 10 branch offices would have aggregate bandwidth licensing
   • IPsec tunnels for site-to-site connectivity

3. Service Connection:
   • Typically included with Prisma Access subscription
   • Connects corporate data centers/HQ to Prisma Access fabric
   • Enables mobile users to access internal resources
   • May have bandwidth considerations for high-throughput needs

4. Security Service Subscriptions:

   Core Services (typically bundled):
   • Threat Prevention (IPS, AV, Anti-Spyware)
   • URL Filtering
   • WildFire
   • DNS Security

   Advanced Services (additional subscriptions):
   • Enterprise DLP: Content inspection, data patterns, ML classification
   • SaaS Security (CASB): Inline and API-based SaaS visibility/control
   • ADEM: Digital experience monitoring across 5 segments
   • IoT Security: Device discovery and profiling
   • Remote Browser Isolation: Isolated browsing for risky sites

   These require separate subscription entitlements beyond base licensing.

Licensing Considerations:
• Initial sizing based on user count and bandwidth requirements
• Can add users/bandwidth as organization grows
• Security services activated through subscription keys
• Cortex Data Lake storage included with retention options

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. Single enterprise license for everything: Prisma Access doesn't offer 'unlimited everything' pricing. User counts, bandwidth, and security services are distinct licensing components with specific entitlements.

C. Purely consumption-based: While there are consumption elements, Prisma Access licensing is primarily capacity-based (users, bandwidth) with committed terms, not pay-as-you-go monthly calculation.

D. Completely separate contracts: While components are licensed differently, they're typically part of a unified Prisma Access agreement, not independent contracts. The licensing is structured but integrated.

Key exam point: Mobile Users = user count, Remote Networks = bandwidth, Security Services = additional subscriptions (DLP, CASB, ADEM).

question:
A compliance officer requests that Prisma Access blocks access to cryptocurrency websites and high-risk financial sites. The security team needs to implement this quickly using built-in capabilities.

Reviewing URL Filtering, they find the organization's current policy allows most URL categories and only blocks malware, phishing, and command-and-control.

Which approach provides the fastest compliant implementation?
options: Modify the URL Filtering profile to add 'cryptocurrency' and 'high-risk' categories to the block list, then push the updated configuration.
Create custom URL categories containing known cryptocurrency domains, then block those custom categories in the security policy.
Deploy a web proxy upstream of Prisma Access to filter cryptocurrency traffic before it reaches the security stack.
Configure DNS Security to sinkhole cryptocurrency-related domain resolutions using a custom DNS policy.
explanation:
Prisma Access URL Filtering includes pre-defined categories for various content types, including cryptocurrency. Using built-in categories provides the fastest implementation.

1. Built-in Categories Available:
   • PAN-DB includes 'cryptocurrency' as a URL category
   • Sites for trading, mining, wallets, and crypto information
   • 'Financial-services' category with risk sub-classifications
   • Categories maintained by Palo Alto threat intelligence
   • No manual list maintenance required

2. Implementation Steps:
   • Navigate to URL Filtering profile in Strata Cloud Manager
   • Locate 'cryptocurrency' category (currently likely set to allow)
   • Change action from 'allow' to 'block'
   • Add other relevant categories (high-risk financial sites)
   • Push configuration
   • Immediate enforcement across all Prisma Access locations

3. Why This Is Fastest:
   • No custom category creation required
   • No domain research or list building
   • Single configuration change, single push
   • Leverages existing threat intelligence
   • Typically deployable in minutes

4. Category Actions Available:
   • Allow: Permit access without restriction
   • Alert: Allow but log for visibility
   • Block: Deny access with block page
   • Continue: Warn user but allow override
   • Override: Require password to access

URL Filtering Profile Structure:
• Each category has an assigned action
• Default action for unlisted categories
• Site access checking enabled/disabled
• Custom block pages configurable

Let's analyze why the other options are slower or less appropriate:

B. Custom URL categories: Creating custom categories requires:
• Researching and compiling domain lists
• Manual entry of domains
• Ongoing maintenance as new sites appear
• Much slower than using built-in categories
• Built-in categories already cover this use case

C. Upstream web proxy: Deploying additional infrastructure is:
• Time-consuming (procurement, installation, configuration)
• Architecturally complex (additional traffic path)
• Redundant—Prisma Access already provides this functionality
• Not a 'quick implementation'

D. DNS Security sinkholing: DNS Security is powerful but:
• Requires creating custom DNS policies
• Doesn't leverage URL category intelligence
• Works at domain level, not URL path level
• URL Filtering is the appropriate tool for category-based blocking

Key exam point: PAN-DB includes cryptocurrency and financial risk categories. Fastest implementation = modify URL Filtering profile actions.

question:
After deploying Prisma Access, the security team notices significant traffic categorized as 'unknown-tcp' and 'unknown-udp' in their logs. Investigation reveals:

• The unknown traffic is going to legitimate cloud SaaS providers
• Traffic occurs on standard HTTPS port 443
• SSL decryption is enabled for these destinations
• The SaaS applications are approved for business use

What explains this behavior and how should it be addressed?
options: The SaaS applications may use custom protocols over HTTPS, or App-ID signatures don't yet exist. Request App-ID signatures from Palo Alto Networks and use application override as temporary workaround.
Unknown traffic indicates the applications are malicious and evading detection. Block all unknown traffic immediately.
SSL decryption is interfering with App-ID. Disable decryption for these destinations to enable proper application identification.
Unknown traffic means the firewall is overloaded and can't perform deep packet inspection. Increase allocated bandwidth.
explanation:
App-ID relies on signatures to identify applications. When applications use non-standard protocols or are new/niche, they may not have signatures yet.

1. Why Traffic Shows as Unknown:

   Possible Causes:
   • Application uses proprietary protocol over HTTPS
   • New/updated SaaS application without current signature
   • Custom or industry-specific application
   • Application behavior doesn't match known signatures
   • Encrypted traffic patterns not recognizable

   What App-ID Sees:
   • SSL/TLS handshake (identifies HTTPS)
   • Decrypted traffic doesn't match any known application patterns
   • Falls back to 'unknown-tcp' on port 443
   • Still logged and can be controlled by policy

2. Addressing the Issue:

   Request App-ID Signature:
   • Submit request to Palo Alto Networks for new signature
   • Provide traffic samples, destination information
   • New signatures added to App-ID updates
   • Once available, traffic properly identified

   Temporary Workaround - Application Override:
   • Create application override policy
   • Match on destination IP/domain and port
   • Assign custom application name
   • Traffic now categorized consistently
   • Enables proper security policy creation

   Alternative - Custom Application:
   • Define custom application in Strata Cloud Manager
   • Specify signatures or simple match criteria
   • Use in security policies
   • Less robust than official App-ID but functional

3. Policy Consideration:
   • 'Unknown' traffic isn't automatically bad
   • Legitimate applications may appear as unknown
   • Blanket blocking unknown could impact business
   • Monitor and categorize progressively

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. Block all unknown traffic: This is overly aggressive. The scenario states these are 'legitimate cloud SaaS providers' that are 'approved for business use.' Blocking would disrupt business operations. Unknown ≠ malicious.

C. Disable SSL decryption: This is backwards. SSL decryption enables deeper inspection for App-ID. Without decryption, App-ID sees only encrypted traffic, which is even harder to identify. Decryption helps, not hurts, identification.

D. Firewall overloaded: 'Unknown' classification isn't a symptom of overload. Overload would cause performance issues, dropped packets, or timeouts—not misclassification. The firewall is correctly classifying traffic as 'unknown' because it lacks signatures.

Key exam point: Unknown applications need signature requests or application override. Unknown ≠ malicious; it means 'not yet identified.'

question:
An organization wants mobile users connecting through Prisma Access to appear with consistent, predictable source IP addresses when accessing a partner's application. The partner's firewall only allows connections from whitelisted IPs.

The current configuration uses dynamic NAT with Prisma Access egress IPs, which change based on compute location.

Which configuration provides consistent source IP addresses for partner access?
options: Configure a dedicated egress IP address pool for traffic destined to the partner's network, using source NAT policy to translate mobile user traffic to these static IPs.
Deploy a service connection to the partner's network, bypassing the internet and NAT entirely.
Configure the partner to whitelist all Prisma Access compute location egress IP ranges globally.
Use GlobalProtect split tunneling to send partner traffic directly from users' local IP addresses.
explanation:
Prisma Access supports dedicated egress IP addresses for scenarios requiring consistent, predictable source IPs for traffic to specific destinations.

1. Dedicated Egress IP Solution:

   How It Works:
   • Reserve static IP addresses from Prisma Access egress pools
   • Configure NAT policy matching destination (partner's network)
   • All matching traffic translated to dedicated IPs
   • Users from any compute location get same source IP
   • Partner whitelists only these specific IPs

   Configuration Steps:
   • In Strata Cloud Manager, navigate to Prisma Access settings
   • Configure dedicated egress IPs (per region as needed)
   • Create NAT rule: source=mobile users, destination=partner network
   • Translate source to dedicated egress IP pool
   • Push configuration

2. Benefits:
   • Predictable source IPs for partner whitelisting
   • Works regardless of which compute location user connects to
   • Maintains full security inspection through Prisma Access
   • No changes needed when users travel or locations change

3. Considerations:
   • Dedicated IPs may have additional cost
   • Limited number of dedicated IPs available
   • Use only where truly required (partner requirements)
   • General internet access can continue using dynamic NAT

Let's analyze why the other options are less suitable:

B. Service connection to partner: This implies direct network connectivity between your infrastructure and the partner's network. Most partner relationships don't involve direct network integration—they're accessed over the internet. Service connections are for connecting to your own data centers, not partners.

C. Whitelist all Prisma Access IPs globally: This is impractical because:
• Prisma Access has 100+ compute locations
• Each location has multiple egress IP ranges
• IP ranges change as infrastructure evolves
• Creates a very large whitelist that's hard to maintain
• Partner may not agree to whitelist thousands of IPs

D. Split tunneling for partner traffic: This would bypass Prisma Access entirely, sending traffic directly from user's local IP. Problems:
• Users have dynamic IPs that change constantly
• No security inspection of partner-bound traffic
• Violates typical security policies
• Impractical for partner whitelisting (too many user IPs)

Key exam point: Dedicated egress IPs provide consistent source NAT for partner/third-party whitelisting requirements.

question:
A financial services company needs to send decrypted traffic copies to additional security tools for analysis. Their requirements include:

• Data loss prevention appliance needs to inspect cleartext traffic
• Network forensics system requires packet capture of decrypted sessions
• Both tools are deployed in the corporate data center
• Traffic must remain encrypted to the original destination

How can this be achieved with Prisma Access?
options: Configure decryption mirroring to forward decrypted traffic copies through the service connection to data center security tools.
Deploy the DLP and forensics tools inline between users and Prisma Access to inspect traffic before encryption.
Export Prisma Access private keys to the security tools so they can passively decrypt traffic captures.
Configure Prisma Access to send all traffic unencrypted to destinations, eliminating the need for additional decryption.
explanation:
Decryption mirroring (also called decryption broker functionality) allows Prisma Access to send copies of decrypted traffic to additional inspection tools while maintaining encryption to the destination.

1. How Decryption Mirroring Works:

   Traffic Flow:
   • User initiates HTTPS connection to destination
   • Prisma Access performs SSL decryption (man-in-the-middle)
   • Decrypted traffic inspected by Prisma Access security stack
   • Copy of decrypted traffic mirrored to configured destinations
   • Original traffic re-encrypted and sent to destination
   • Destination receives normal encrypted connection

2. Configuration Elements:

   Decryption Mirror Profile:
   • Specifies where to send mirrored traffic
   • Can filter by application, URL category, etc.
   • Forwards through network interface (typically service connection)

   Service Connection Path:
   • Mirrored traffic routed through service connection to data center
   • DLP appliance and forensics tools receive cleartext copies
   • Low latency path for real-time analysis

3. Security Tool Integration:

   DLP Appliance:
   • Receives cleartext for content inspection
   • Can detect sensitive data patterns
   • Complements Prisma Access built-in DLP

   Network Forensics:
   • Captures decrypted packets for investigation
   • Full session reconstruction capability
   • Historical analysis for incident response

4. Key Point - Destination Encryption:
   • Mirror is a copy; original traffic continues normally
   • Destination receives properly encrypted connection
   • End-to-end encryption maintained for actual communication
   • Only internal copies are cleartext

Let's analyze why the other options don't work:

B. Tools inline between users and Prisma Access: This is architecturally impossible. Mobile users connect directly to Prisma Access over the internet. There's no inline position between users and cloud service. The service connection provides the integration point, not inline placement.

C. Export private keys: Prisma Access dynamically generates certificates for each intercepted session. There's no static private key to export. Additionally, passive decryption would miss Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) sessions. Mirroring is the supported approach.

D. Send traffic unencrypted: This would expose all traffic in cleartext across the internet—a massive security vulnerability. The requirement is to maintain encryption to destinations while providing decrypted copies internally. Removing encryption is not acceptable.

Key exam point: Decryption mirroring sends cleartext copies to security tools while maintaining encryption to destinations.

question:
A user reports slow GlobalProtect performance despite having fast local internet connectivity. ADEM shows:

• Endpoint segment: 5ms (healthy)
• LAN segment: 3ms (healthy)
• ISP segment: 180ms (degraded)
• Internet segment: 8ms (healthy)
• Application segment: 15ms (healthy)

Further investigation reveals the user is located in Singapore but connecting to a GlobalProtect gateway in the US West region.

What is causing the suboptimal gateway selection?
options: The GlobalProtect portal configuration may have specific gateway assignments or the Singapore compute location may not be enabled in the Prisma Access configuration.
The user's ISP is routing traffic inefficiently, and GlobalProtect cannot compensate for carrier routing decisions.
ADEM measurements are inaccurate because the user is outside their normal location.
GlobalProtect always connects to the gateway with lowest load, and Singapore gateway was overloaded.
explanation:
GlobalProtect gateway selection is influenced by configuration settings, not just automatic optimization. Suboptimal selection often results from configuration issues.

1. Why User Connects to US West Instead of Singapore:

   Possible Configuration Issues:

   A. Gateway Priority/Assignment in Portal:
   • Portal configuration specifies which gateways users can connect to
   • Manual priority settings may prioritize US West
   • Geographic-based assignment rules may be missing or incorrect
   • User may be assigned to 'wrong' gateway pool

   B. Compute Location Not Enabled:
   • Prisma Access compute locations must be explicitly enabled
   • Singapore location may not be licensed/configured
   • Organization may have selected only US regions
   • User forced to connect to nearest enabled location

   C. Agent Configuration:
   • GlobalProtect agent settings may specify gateway
   • Previous connection preference cached
   • Manual gateway selection by user (if allowed)

2. Understanding the ADEM Data:
   • ISP segment 180ms = high latency from user to Prisma Access
   • This makes sense for Singapore → US West path (transpacific)
   • Once traffic reaches US West (Internet + App segments), latency is normal
   • The problem is the long path to reach the gateway

3. Resolution Steps:
   • Verify Singapore compute location is enabled in Prisma Access
   • Check portal gateway configuration for this user/group
   • Review gateway selection method (automatic vs. manual)
   • Ensure geographic-based selection is configured

4. Expected Behavior with Correct Configuration:
   • User in Singapore should connect to APAC gateway
   • Total latency would be similar across all segments (low)
   • ISP segment should be <30ms to nearby compute location

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. ISP routing inefficiency: While ISP routing affects latency, the core issue is connecting to a gateway in the wrong region. Even with perfect ISP routing, Singapore to US West will have high latency due to physical distance. The configuration should direct users to nearby gateways.

C. ADEM inaccurate outside normal location: ADEM measurements are valid regardless of user location. The tool is designed for mobile users who travel. The 180ms ISP segment accurately reflects the long path to the distant gateway.

D. Lowest load selection: GlobalProtect doesn't use 'lowest load' as primary selection criteria. Selection is based on geography and configuration. Load balancing occurs within a region, not across continents. Sending Singapore users to US for 'load balancing' would be architectural malpractice.

Key exam point: Gateway selection is configuration-driven. Check portal settings and enabled compute locations when users connect to distant gateways.

question:
A security team needs to configure file blocking in Prisma Access to prevent malware delivery while allowing legitimate business file transfers. Their requirements include:

• Block executable files from being downloaded via web browsing
• Allow executable file uploads to approved software distribution sites
• Block encrypted archives that can't be inspected
• Allow standard business documents (Office, PDF) in both directions

Which TWO file blocking configurations are needed?
options: Create a rule blocking PE (Portable Executable) files on download direction with action 'block', applying to web-browsing and ssl applications.
Configure encrypted file blocking for 'encrypted-zip' and 'encrypted-rar' file types with action 'block' in both directions.
Create a single rule blocking all file types and add exceptions only for approved domains.
Enable 'Strict Mode' file blocking to automatically block all files not explicitly allowed.
explanation:
File blocking profiles enable granular control over file transfers based on file type, direction, and application. Two specific configurations address the requirements:

A. Block PE Files on Download:

   Why PE Files:
   • PE (Portable Executable) = Windows executables (.exe, .dll, .scr, etc.)
   • Primary vector for malware delivery
   • Downloaded via web browsing during drive-by attacks
   • Rarely legitimately needed from random websites

   Configuration:
   • File type: PE
   • Direction: Download
   • Applications: web-browsing, ssl
   • Action: Block

   Why Direction Matters:
   • Download = receiving from external sources (high risk)
   • Upload to 'approved software distribution sites' still allowed
   • Block rule specifies download direction only
   • Separate rule or no rule for upload direction

   Effect:
   • User trying to download .exe from web: BLOCKED
   • User uploading .exe to approved site: ALLOWED
   • Reduces drive-by malware risk

B. Block Encrypted Archives:

   Why Encrypted Archives:
   • Encrypted ZIP/RAR files can't be inspected
   • Malware hidden inside evades antivirus, DLP, WildFire
   • Common malware delivery technique
   • Password sent separately to victim

   File Types:
   • encrypted-zip: Password-protected ZIP archives
   • encrypted-rar: Password-protected RAR archives
   • encrypted-7z: Password-protected 7-Zip archives

   Configuration:
   • File types: encrypted-zip, encrypted-rar, encrypted-7z
   • Direction: Both (upload and download)
   • Action: Block

   Effect:
   • Any password-protected archive: BLOCKED
   • Standard (unencrypted) archives: ALLOWED (can be inspected)
   • Prevents uninspectable file bypass

Implicit Allow for Documents:
   • Office files (doc, docx, xls, xlsx, ppt, pptx)
   • PDF files
   • Not explicitly blocked, therefore allowed
   • Can be inspected by antivirus and WildFire

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

C. Block all, add exceptions: This is overly restrictive and operationally complex. Maintaining exception lists for every allowed domain is burdensome. The requirement allows 'standard business documents in both directions'—blocking everything by default doesn't match this intent.

D. 'Strict Mode' file blocking: This setting doesn't exist. File blocking is configured through file blocking profiles with explicit rules for file types and directions, not a global 'strict mode' toggle.

Key exam point: File blocking uses: file type + direction + application + action. PE files and encrypted archives are common block targets.

question:
An organization is evaluating how Prisma Access security services receive updates. They want to understand the difference between content updates for threat signatures and new security capabilities.

Which statement accurately describes how Prisma Access security services are updated?
options: Threat signatures (Antivirus, Anti-Spyware, Vulnerability) are updated multiple times daily automatically, while new security capabilities are delivered through platform updates managed by Palo Alto Networks.
All security updates require manual approval and scheduled maintenance windows before deployment to Prisma Access.
Organizations must download content updates from the Palo Alto support portal and upload them to Strata Cloud Manager for deployment.
Security updates are only applied when the organization renews their subscription, typically annually.
explanation:
Prisma Access as a cloud service benefits from automated, continuous security updates managed by Palo Alto Networks.

1. Threat Signature Updates (Automatic, Frequent):

   What's Updated:
   • Antivirus signatures: New malware definitions
   • Anti-Spyware signatures: C2 callbacks, spyware behaviors
   • Vulnerability signatures: New exploit protections
   • URL categories: Newly categorized websites
   • WildFire signatures: Malware discovered through analysis

   Update Frequency:
   • Multiple times per day (typically every few hours)
   • Emergency signatures deployed within minutes of discovery
   • No customer action required
   • Automatic across all compute locations globally

   How It Works:
   • Palo Alto threat intelligence team creates signatures
   • Content pushed to cloud content delivery network
   • Prisma Access infrastructure pulls updates automatically
   • Customers receive protection without intervention

2. Platform Updates (Managed by Palo Alto Networks):

   What's Updated:
   • New security features and capabilities
   • App-ID updates for new applications
   • Engine improvements
   • Bug fixes and performance enhancements

   Update Process:
   • Palo Alto Networks manages infrastructure updates
   • Rolled out across regions with minimal disruption
   • Customers don't manage PAN-OS versions
   • Cloud-native approach vs. appliance maintenance

3. Customer Responsibility:
   • Configure security policies to use updated signatures
   • Ensure appropriate licenses/subscriptions are active
   • Monitor for any policy adjustments needed
   • No manual update deployment required

Cloud-Delivered vs. On-Premises Difference:
   • On-premises NGFW: Customer schedules and installs content updates
   • Prisma Access: Updates delivered automatically by Palo Alto Networks
   • Significantly reduced operational overhead
   • Consistent protection level globally

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. Manual approval and maintenance windows: This describes traditional on-premises appliance management, not cloud services. Prisma Access updates are automatic; customers don't schedule maintenance windows for content updates.

C. Download from support portal: This describes the legacy process for on-premises firewalls. Prisma Access doesn't require manual content downloads or uploads. The cloud infrastructure manages all content delivery.

D. Updates only on subscription renewal: This is completely incorrect. Active subscriptions receive continuous updates throughout the subscription period. Updates occur multiple times daily, not annually.

Key exam point: Prisma Access = automatic content updates multiple times daily. Platform updates managed by Palo Alto Networks. No customer update management required.

question:
An organization uses a third-party SD-WAN solution for branch connectivity and wants to integrate with Prisma Access. Their requirements include:

• SD-WAN handles local internet breakout for trusted SaaS applications
• Branch traffic to corporate resources should go through Prisma Access
• Security policies should be consistent whether traffic goes direct or through Prisma Access
• The solution should work with their existing SD-WAN vendor investment

Which integration approach best addresses these requirements?
options: Configure Remote Network connections from SD-WAN edges to Prisma Access using IPsec tunnels, with SD-WAN traffic policies directing corporate-bound traffic through the tunnels.
Replace the SD-WAN solution with Prisma SD-WAN to achieve native integration with Prisma Access.
Deploy GlobalProtect agents on all branch devices to bypass the SD-WAN for Prisma Access connectivity.
Configure BGP peering directly between SD-WAN edges and Prisma Access without IPsec tunnels.
explanation:
Prisma Access integrates with third-party SD-WAN solutions through Remote Network IPsec tunnels, allowing organizations to leverage existing SD-WAN investments.

1. Integration Architecture:

   SD-WAN Edge → IPsec Tunnel → Prisma Access Remote Network

   Traffic Flow:
   • SD-WAN traffic policies determine traffic steering
   • Trusted SaaS (Microsoft 365, Salesforce): Local internet breakout
   • Corporate resources, security-sensitive traffic: IPsec to Prisma Access
   • Prisma Access provides security inspection for tunneled traffic

2. Configuration Components:

   SD-WAN Edge (Third-party device):
   • IPsec tunnel configuration to Prisma Access endpoints
   • IKEv2 with appropriate crypto profiles
   • Traffic policies: which traffic goes through tunnel
   • BGP or static routes for Prisma Access integration

   Prisma Access (Remote Network):
   • IPsec tunnel configuration matching SD-WAN
   • Remote Network for each SD-WAN site or hub
   • Security policies applied to tunneled traffic
   • Routing back to SD-WAN for return traffic

3. Addressing Each Requirement:

   Local Breakout for Trusted SaaS:
   • SD-WAN policies identify trusted apps (M365, etc.)
   • Direct internet path, bypassing Prisma Access
   • Optimized performance for latency-sensitive SaaS

   Corporate Resources Through Prisma Access:
   • SD-WAN steers corporate-bound traffic to IPsec tunnel
   • Full security inspection at Prisma Access
   • Service connection provides path to data center

   Consistent Security Policies:
   • Traffic through Prisma Access gets full policy enforcement
   • Local breakout relies on SD-WAN security (vendor-dependent)
   • Many customers accept reduced inspection for trusted SaaS

   Existing SD-WAN Investment:
   • No SD-WAN replacement required
   • Works with most SD-WAN vendors (Cisco, VMware, Aruba, etc.)
   • IPsec is universal standard

4. Supported SD-WAN Vendors:
   • Cisco Viptela/Meraki
   • VMware VeloCloud
   • Aruba/Silver Peak
   • Fortinet
   • Many others with IPsec support

Let's analyze why the other options are less suitable:

B. Replace with Prisma SD-WAN: This ignores the 'existing SD-WAN vendor investment' requirement. Replacing infrastructure is expensive and time-consuming. Integration preserves existing investment.

C. GlobalProtect on branch devices: This is architecturally wrong for branch connectivity. GlobalProtect is for individual devices (mobile users), not site connectivity. SD-WAN provides site-level connectivity; adding per-device VPN is redundant and complex.

D. BGP without IPsec: BGP provides routing, not secure transport. Without IPsec encryption, traffic would traverse the internet in cleartext. This is not a secure architecture for branch-to-cloud connectivity.

Key exam point: Third-party SD-WAN integration = Remote Network IPsec tunnels. SD-WAN policies control traffic steering.

question:
A large enterprise is implementing Strata Cloud Manager for Prisma Access administration. Their security operations model requires:

• Network team manages connectivity (Remote Networks, Service Connections)
• Security team manages policies and profiles
• SOC analysts need read-only access for monitoring and troubleshooting
• Only security architects can modify decryption policies

Which SCM capability enables this administrative model?
options: Role-based access control (RBAC) with custom roles defining specific permissions for configuration areas, combined with access domains for scope limitation.
Multiple administrator accounts with shared credentials per team function.
Separate SCM tenant instances for each administrative team with data synchronization between them.
Workflow approval system where changes require sign-off from all teams before implementation.
explanation:
Strata Cloud Manager includes comprehensive Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to support enterprise administrative models with separation of duties.

1. RBAC Components in SCM:

   Roles:
   • Define what actions users can perform
   • Built-in roles: Administrator, Security Admin, Network Admin, Read-Only
   • Custom roles: Create specific permission sets
   • Granular permissions for each configuration area

   Access Domains:
   • Define scope of access (which resources)
   • Can limit visibility to specific sites, policies, or tenants
   • Combines with roles: permissions + scope

2. Implementation for Requirements:

   Network Team:
   • Custom role: Network Admin
   • Permissions: Full access to Remote Networks, Service Connections, IPsec
   • Restricted from: Security policies, security profiles
   • Can configure tunnels but not policy

   Security Team:
   • Custom role: Security Admin
   • Permissions: Full access to security policies, profiles (except decryption)
   • Restricted from: Network infrastructure
   • Can create/modify policy rules

   SOC Analysts:
   • Built-in role: Read-Only
   • Permissions: View all configurations and logs
   • Restricted from: Any modifications
   • Can monitor and investigate

   Security Architects:
   • Custom role: Decryption Admin
   • Permissions: Full access to SSL decryption policies
   • This is a sensitive area requiring limited access
   • May also have broader security permissions

3. How RBAC Enables Separation:
   • Each user assigned appropriate role
   • Authentication through identity provider (SSO)
   • Audit logging tracks who changed what
   • Reduces risk of unauthorized changes
   • Enables compliance with security frameworks

Let's analyze why the other options are incorrect:

B. Shared credentials per team: This is a security anti-pattern. Shared credentials eliminate accountability (who made which change?), violate compliance requirements, and create security risks. Individual accounts with RBAC is the proper approach.

C. Separate SCM tenants: This creates operational silos. Separate tenants mean separate configurations that must be synchronized manually. It doesn't enable collaboration within a shared Prisma Access deployment. Multitenancy exists for different customers, not different internal teams.

D. Workflow approval system: While workflow/approval systems exist in some contexts, SCM doesn't require all-team sign-off for changes. RBAC allows teams to work independently within their permission boundaries without blocking each other.

Key exam point: RBAC = roles (permissions) + access domains (scope). Custom roles enable separation of duties for different teams.

question:
Mobile users connecting through GlobalProtect report that internal DNS resolution is not working. Investigation reveals:

• Users can reach internal applications by IP address
• DNS queries for internal domains (corp.local) timeout or fail
• External DNS resolution works correctly
• The internal DNS servers are located in the corporate data center

What configuration is needed to resolve this issue?
options: Configure DNS Proxy in Prisma Access to forward queries for internal domains to internal DNS servers through the service connection.
Install internal DNS server certificates on user endpoints to establish trust for DNS-over-HTTPS.
Configure GlobalProtect to bypass the VPN tunnel for all DNS traffic.
Deploy public DNS records for all internal domains to enable resolution without internal servers.
explanation:
DNS Proxy in Prisma Access forwards queries for specific internal domains to designated internal DNS servers.

The Problem:
• Internal domains (corp.local) exist only on internal DNS servers
• Public DNS has no records for these internal zones
• Mobile users need internal DNS access for name resolution

DNS Proxy Solution:
• Configure DNS Proxy in Strata Cloud Manager
• Specify internal domain suffixes (e.g., corp.local)
• Point to internal DNS server IPs reachable via service connection
• Internal queries forwarded through service connection to data center DNS

Why other options are incorrect:

B. DNS server certificates: This relates to DNS-over-HTTPS encryption, not DNS routing. The issue is reaching the correct DNS server, not certificate trust.

C. Bypass VPN for DNS: This would send DNS queries to the internet, making internal resolution impossible.

D. Public DNS records: Publishing internal IPs in public DNS is a security risk and doesn't solve internal name resolution.

Key point: DNS Proxy forwards internal domain queries to corporate DNS servers through the service connection.

question:
A security operations center needs to analyze traffic patterns for threat hunting using their own network detection and response (NDR) platform. They require:

• Copy of traffic metadata (not full packet capture)
• Real-time streaming to their on-premises NDR
• Minimal impact on Prisma Access performance
• Integration without modifying traffic flow

Which Prisma Access capability supports this requirement?
options: Configure log forwarding to stream enhanced traffic logs containing flow metadata to the NDR platform via syslog or HTTPS.
Deploy network TAPs at Prisma Access compute locations to capture traffic copies.
Configure port mirroring on Prisma Access infrastructure to send traffic copies to NDR.
Use Prisma Access API to poll for traffic data every 5 seconds for near-real-time analysis.
explanation:
Log forwarding provides traffic metadata streaming without full packet capture, meeting the NDR integration requirements.

1. Enhanced Traffic Logs:

   What's Included:
   • Source/destination IP addresses and ports
   • Application identification (App-ID)
   • User identity (if available)
   • URL information for web traffic
   • Threat indicators if detected
   • Bytes sent/received
   • Session duration and flags
   • Rule matched and action taken

   This is 'traffic metadata' without full packet payload.

2. Log Forwarding Configuration:

   Syslog Method:
   • Configure log forwarding profile in Strata Cloud Manager
   • Define syslog server (NDR platform endpoint)
   • Select log types: Traffic, Threat, URL, etc.
   • Choose format: CEF, LEEF, or custom
   • Real-time streaming as events occur

   HTTPS Method:
   • Forward to HTTPS endpoints
   • TLS encryption for log transport
   • Suitable for cloud-based NDR platforms

3. Meeting Requirements:

   Traffic Metadata (Not Full Capture):
   • Logs contain flow information, not packets
   • Suitable for behavioral analysis and threat hunting
   • Much lower bandwidth than full PCAP

   Real-Time Streaming:
   • Log forwarding is continuous
   • Events sent within seconds of occurrence
   • NDR receives near-real-time feed

   Minimal Performance Impact:
   • Logging is inherent to Prisma Access operation
   • Forwarding adds minimal overhead
   • No inline processing changes

   No Traffic Flow Modification:
   • Logs are a side channel
   • Actual traffic path unchanged
   • NDR is passive recipient

4. Cortex Data Lake Alternative:
   • Logs stored in Cortex Data Lake
   • Can query via API or use XDR integration
   • Not direct streaming to external NDR
   • Syslog forwarding is direct path to external tools

Let's analyze why the other options don't work:

B. Network TAPs at compute locations: Customers don't have physical access to Prisma Access compute locations. TAP deployment is not possible in a cloud-delivered service. The infrastructure is managed by Palo Alto Networks.

C. Port mirroring on infrastructure: Similar to TAPs, customers cannot configure port mirroring on Prisma Access infrastructure. There's no customer access to switching/routing layers within the cloud service.

D. API polling every 5 seconds: This isn't real-time and would be extremely inefficient. Polling creates latency and overhead. Log forwarding pushes events as they occur, which is more efficient and timely.

Key exam point: Log forwarding (syslog/HTTPS) = real-time traffic metadata streaming to external security tools.

question:
A security architect is explaining ZTNA 2.0 principles to leadership. They need to differentiate ZTNA 2.0 from traditional ZTNA 1.0 approaches.

Which THREE capabilities are unique to or significantly enhanced in ZTNA 2.0 compared to ZTNA 1.0?
options: Continuous trust verification that monitors user and device behavior throughout the session, not just at connection time.
Deep application inspection using App-ID to understand and control application behavior, not just access authorization.
Application access limited to web applications using HTTP/HTTPS protocols only.
Support for all applications including legacy client-server apps with server-initiated connections.
Network segmentation based on VLAN assignment after successful authentication.
explanation:
ZTNA 2.0 represents Palo Alto Networks' evolution of Zero Trust Network Access, addressing limitations in first-generation ZTNA solutions.

1. A. Continuous Trust Verification (Correct):

   ZTNA 1.0 Limitation:
   • Trust established at connection time (authenticate → access)
   • No ongoing verification during session
   • Compromised device/account retains access

   ZTNA 2.0 Enhancement:
   • Continuous monitoring throughout session
   • Device posture checked repeatedly (not just initially)
   • User behavior analysis for anomalies
   • Session can be terminated if trust conditions change
   • 'Never trust, always verify' applies continuously

2. B. Deep Application Inspection with App-ID (Correct):

   ZTNA 1.0 Limitation:
   • Provides access to application (TCP/UDP connectivity)
   • No visibility into what happens within the session
   • Can't differentiate application features/functions
   • 'Allow access or deny'—binary decision

   ZTNA 2.0 Enhancement:
   • App-ID identifies specific applications and functions
   • Can allow 'slack-base' but block 'slack-file-transfer'
   • Visibility into application behavior
   • Control at feature level, not just app level
   • Applies security profiles to traffic

3. D. Support for All Applications Including Bidirectional (Correct):

   ZTNA 1.0 Limitation:
   • Primarily supports web/HTTP-based applications
   • Client-initiates-only connection model
   • Struggles with legacy client-server apps
   • Server-to-client callbacks problematic

   ZTNA 2.0 Enhancement:
   • Supports any TCP/UDP application
   • Bidirectional connections supported
   • Legacy applications (thick clients) work properly
   • Server-initiated connections routed correctly
   • ZTNA Connector handles complex app architectures

Let's analyze why the other options are NOT ZTNA 2.0 differentiators:

C. Limited to HTTP/HTTPS: This describes a ZTNA 1.0 limitation, not a ZTNA 2.0 capability. ZTNA 2.0 specifically addresses this limitation by supporting all protocols.

E. VLAN-based segmentation: This is a traditional network segmentation approach, not Zero Trust. ZTNA moves away from network-based access to application-based access. VLANs are layer 2 network concepts, not Zero Trust principles.

Key exam point: ZTNA 2.0 = continuous trust verification + deep app inspection (App-ID) + all apps/protocols + bidirectional support.

question:
An organization's security policy requires that mobile users cannot communicate directly with each other through Prisma Access. They want to prevent potential lateral movement if a user's device is compromised.

Current observation shows that mobile users in the same Prisma Access deployment can ping each other's internal IPs.

What configuration change prevents this intra-user communication?
options: Configure security policy to deny intrazone traffic within the mobile user zone, blocking user-to-user communication while allowing user-to-destination traffic.
Deploy each user to a separate VLAN within Prisma Access to provide network isolation.
Disable the internal IP address assignment for mobile users, using NAT for all connections.
Configure GlobalProtect in 'Isolated Mode' to prevent tunnel splitting between users.
explanation:
Intrazone traffic control through security policy is the mechanism to prevent mobile users from communicating with each other.

1. Understanding the Traffic Flow:

   Default Behavior:
   • Mobile users receive internal IPs from Prisma Access pools
   • Users are in the same logical zone (mobile-user zone)
   • Intrazone traffic (same zone to same zone) is allowed by default
   • User A can reach User B's internal IP through Prisma Access

   Security Concern:
   • Compromised device could scan for other mobile users
   • Lateral movement within mobile user population
   • Malware propagation between user devices
   • Not following least-privilege principle

2. Solution - Deny Intrazone Policy:

   Configuration:
   • Create security policy rule
   • Source zone: Mobile-User (or equivalent)
   • Source: Mobile user address range
   • Destination zone: Mobile-User (same zone)
   • Destination: Mobile user address range
   • Action: Deny
   • Position: Before any allow rules for this zone pair

   Effect:
   • User A trying to reach User B's IP: DENIED
   • User A reaching destination servers: ALLOWED (different rule)
   • Prevents lateral movement between users
   • Each user isolated from other users

3. What Still Works:
   • User → Internet: Allowed (different destination)
   • User → Corporate resources: Allowed (via service connection)
   • User → SaaS applications: Allowed
   • User → Other User: BLOCKED

4. Implementation:
   • Works at Layer 3/4 (IP and port level)
   • Can be enhanced with App-ID for specific applications
   • Logged for visibility
   • Standard security policy mechanism

Let's analyze why the other options don't apply:

B. Separate VLANs per user: Prisma Access is a cloud service; customers don't configure VLANs within the infrastructure. The zone and policy model provides logical separation without VLAN management.

C. Disable internal IP assignment: Users need internal IPs for consistent addressing, especially for accessing corporate resources that use IP-based access control. NAT-only doesn't prevent user-to-user routing—the infrastructure still knows routes.

D. 'Isolated Mode': This setting doesn't exist in GlobalProtect. Isolation is achieved through security policy, not client configuration modes.

Key exam point: Deny intrazone policy controls user-to-user communication. Same zone doesn't mean same access—policy defines what's allowed.

question:
Users complain that GlobalProtect frequently prompts for re-authentication, sometimes multiple times per day. The security team wants to reduce authentication friction while maintaining security.

Current configuration:
• SAML authentication with Azure AD
• Authentication timeout: 1 hour
• Cookie lifetime: 1 hour
• Users work 8-10 hour shifts

What configuration change reduces authentication prompts while maintaining appropriate security?
options: Increase the authentication cookie lifetime to match the typical work shift (8-12 hours) while keeping SAML session controls in Azure AD for security enforcement.
Disable authentication entirely and rely on device certificates for identity.
Configure 'Remember Me' in GlobalProtect to store username and password locally.
Set the authentication timeout to 'Never' to eliminate all re-authentication requirements.
explanation:
Authentication cookie lifetime controls how long a user remains authenticated without re-prompting. Adjusting this to match work patterns reduces friction.

1. Understanding Authentication Components:

   Authentication Timeout (Portal/Gateway):
   • How long until user must re-authenticate
   • Clock starts from initial authentication
   • When reached, prompts for credentials

   Cookie Lifetime:
   • Authentication token stored on device
   • Allows session resumption without full re-authentication
   • If cookie valid, no prompt needed
   • Typically should match or exceed authentication timeout

   SAML Session (Azure AD side):
   • Identity provider controls session duration
   • Can enforce MFA, conditional access
   • Independent from GlobalProtect settings
   • Provides additional security control

2. Current Problem Analysis:
   • 1-hour timeout during 8-10 hour shifts
   • Users re-authenticate 8-10 times per day
   • Significant friction and productivity impact
   • Timeout too short for work pattern

3. Recommended Solution:

   Increase Cookie Lifetime:
   • Set to 8-12 hours (matching shift length)
   • User authenticates once at shift start
   • Cookie remains valid through work day
   • Re-authenticate next day or after cookie expires

   Maintain Security via Azure AD:
   • Azure AD conditional access policies
   • MFA requirements at Azure AD level
   • Device compliance checks
   • Risk-based authentication
   • Security controls not just on timeout

4. Balanced Approach:
   • Reduce friction: Fewer daily prompts
   • Maintain security: Azure AD policies active
   • Consider: Shorter timeout for sensitive resources
   • Consider: Re-authentication for specific applications

Let's analyze why the other options are problematic:

B. Device certificates only: This eliminates user identity verification. If device is stolen (but locked), certificate could still authenticate. Multi-factor (certificate + user auth) is stronger than single factor.

C. 'Remember Me' storing credentials: Storing passwords locally is a security risk. Credential theft from endpoint becomes trivial. This is not a recommended security practice.

D. Timeout 'Never': This creates excessive risk. A session that never expires means stolen devices have indefinite access. Some reasonable timeout is necessary for security. 8-12 hours is reasonable; never is not.

Key exam point: Cookie lifetime controls re-authentication frequency. Match to work patterns while maintaining IdP-level security controls.

question:
A custom internal application uses TCP port 8888 for communication. App-ID identifies this traffic as 'unknown-tcp'. The security team wants to:

• Properly identify this traffic in logs and reports
• Apply specific security policies to this application
• Enable QoS prioritization for this application
• Avoid submitting signature requests and waiting for App-ID updates

Which approach achieves these goals immediately?
options: Create an application override policy that assigns a custom application name to traffic matching the destination port and server IP, enabling immediate identification and policy control.
Modify the application's source code to use a standard port that App-ID already recognizes.
Configure URL Filtering to categorize the application's traffic based on HTTP headers.
Wait for the next App-ID content update which automatically learns new applications from customer traffic.
explanation:
Application override allows immediate custom application identification without waiting for official App-ID signatures.
